description: From Middle English apprentice, apprentesse, apprentyse, apprentis, from Old French aprentis, plural of aprentif, from Old French aprendre (verb), Late Latin apprendō, from Classical Latin apprehendō.

entries.meaning: A trainee, especially in a skilled trade.

(historical) One who is bound by indentures or by legal agreement to serve a tradesperson, or other person, for a certain time, with a view to learn the art, or trade, in which his master is bound to instruct him.
(dated) One not well versed in a subject; a tyro or newbie.

verbs.description: apprentice (third-person singular simple present apprentices, present participle apprenticing, simple past and past participle apprenticed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put under the care and supervision of a master, for the purpose of instruction in a trade or business.
examples: His father had apprenticed him to a silk merchant.
He was apprenticed to a local employer.
Joe apprenticed three different photographers before setting up his own studio.
